Author: Regnar#6164
Content: @jl777c I'm thinking of adding a couple of steps to this process (for marketing reasons), not to affect the ease of requests or anything.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: Basically they already provide their logo (to be used on barterDEX) so we use that for the poster, and they should provide the email of their social media contact. Someone on our team, or me or whatever, would basically add their logo to a template that shows they are now supported on BarterDEX, with Komodo logos, social media handle, etc and theirs. and we provide it to their social media account holder so they can post the promotional material on their twitter, reddit, etc

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok by me, just tell me when I can approve a pull request

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: someone that is part of the process needs to give a "ready to merge" comment on each pull request, I can go with that

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: okay @benohanlon  @Steve Lee I'm not sure who we want to put on this part? I think we could just add an optional step in the readme that says have their social media contact email  X address. or something. in the nature of Komodo, it shouldn't be mandatory to be listed, but should be a way for mutual marketing benefits

Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
2. Icon file (Required)
‚Ä¢    The icon file is required.
‚Ä¢    Icon must be a .png format file.
‚Ä¢    Dimensions of icon file is 82x82 pixels.
‚Ä¢    Icon file name MUST be in small letters.
‚Ä¢    Icon file location is icons directory.
‚Ä¢    Send a (XX) sized PNG file of your logo in an email to (XXX) from your social media/marketing lead‚Äôs email to receive joint marketing material upon integration (Optional)
 

I'm thinking something like this, just put in whoever is going to handle the template, adding their logos and emailing it back. This way they can still add to barterDEX (jl777 doesn't have to wait for merge approvals) and we can still get some joint marketing

Content: but yea, the receiver of the email might have to make sure they have posted the request to github, and if jl approved the merge, we can send out the email? or do we send out the email just before the approval? I don't think there is too big a difference in the order of this aspect. just as long as we don't send the email when it's not going to be listed

Author: benohanlon#1119
Content:
Yes @Daniel CP @Regnar I've submitted an idea to @Steve Lee where we would create a series of evergreen posts... each post focuses on one coin that BarterDEX supports with a one line description of what that coin is about + tags their community into it and uses their currency ticker.

These kind of posts can be created once and sent out once or twice a day randomly using a tool like meetedgar to help bring other communities to us and showcase how many coins are supported and educated people.

This is on hold until we have liquidity - I believe @Steve Lee concern is that we'll be pushing people onto barterdex / hyperdex and there won't be enough liquidity to allow them to buy / sell anything.

Author: benohanlon#1119
Content: It would include a graphic too... ideally sourced from their community for a bounty to engage them.

`you know what I mean`
yes, and I also know it's dumb to let wrong people change the meaning of the space

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: But it's better off to explain in laymens terms and compare it to stuff they understand

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: in this instance, it's really not; words matter

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: on this topic, it's not just a matter of semantics, it's an entire conceptual shift

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: for crypto to succeed, the `currency` part of `cryptocurrency` must be in the forefront; otherwise, were all just messing about with commodities and no real adoption will ever take hold

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: Yes for sure, but for example when we switched to the euro in 2000 over here, a lot of people were (and still are) calculating how much is was in the previous currency. So expect the same thing to happen even when the big shift to crypto happens. It's in the nature of people that change is hard for them and don't think you can change that.

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: Basically, it's hard to change that it's hard for people to change. (lol)
